title: Need to Bring Back the Five Lives
content:
I have been a Duolingo user since 2016, before Duolingo went public. This is an incredible app to learn various languages and it has helped me better my Arabic and continue to refresh my French and German. The user friendliness of the app has also improved since I began using the app. 

I am not sure when the update happened, but I do not like the updated energy bar. I used to be able to use my lives, one per lesson and the recharge was much quicker and kept me motivated to learn. Now I have to wait over 12 hours for a full recharge, spend hundreds in gems or $13. In addition, the fact that if I run out of energy halfway through the lesson and will loose all of my XP due to not selecting one of the options above, is incredibly discouraging. The app now officially feels like the developers are putting profits first. I have introduced close friends and family to this app and want to continue to promote Duolingo, but unsure I will because it is harder to maintain the drive to learn with these energy roadblocks.

title: Duolingo: Learning a Language Has Never Been This Addictive
content:
Duolingo isn‚Äôt just an app‚Äîit‚Äôs a little green owl that somehow makes learning a language feel like a game. From the moment you pick your language, you‚Äôre thrown into bite-sized lessons that are easy to fit into even the busiest day. Vocabulary, grammar, listening, and speaking all come together in a colorful, interactive way that keeps you hooked.
The gamification is genius. XP points, streaks, and tiny rewards make you feel like every lesson is a victory, and Duo, the owl, is both motivating and hilariously guilt-trippy when you skip a day. Plus, with dozens of languages (yes, even Klingon), there‚Äôs something for everyone.
It‚Äôs not perfect‚Äîadvanced learners might find it shallow, and some exercises repeat a lot‚Äîbut for beginners or anyone who wants to practice consistently, it‚Äôs almost impossible to put down. Duolingo doesn‚Äôt just teach words; it makes you want to learn them.
In short: it‚Äôs fun, addictive, and surprisingly effective. Duo the owl might just become your new best friend.

I‚Äôve been learning Portuguese on this app for 125 days.

The good: 
-They have definitely taken some psychology classes and mastered how to motivate me! I hardly ever forget daily practice (I have ADHD, so that‚Äôs a BIG deal).
-Each lesson is the perfect length. 
-The aesthetics and sounds are pleasing. 
-It‚Äôs super fun to root on and team up with my family members and friends who have the app.

The cnot so good: 
-In this learning phase it would be wonderful to have an original verb spelling reveal/clue link since that influences most of the latter forms. I have had to buy a Portuguese/English dictionary to look them up.
-They really need to install a vacation option. It‚Äôs really okay to take a break once in a while and not be penalized.
-The lesson and word priorities of the developers is baffling. Very early on (unit 4) they introduce animal names‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not sure why it is so important to know the Portuguese word for ‚Äúshark‚Äù, ‚Äúwolf‚Äù, or ‚Äúarmadillo‚Äù when I can‚Äôt even have a simple conversation in Portuguese yet!

title: An ok supplement to language classes
content:
Duolingo is ok as a supplement if you‚Äôre taking other language classes, but I wouldn‚Äôt trust it on its own to teach me a new language. Especially for language with their own alphabet or strict grammatical rules. I‚Äôm doing their Japanese lesson and they only require you to learn a certain amount of the katakana and hiragana before moving onto lessons, and it can get quite confusing if you haven‚Äôt gotten through all the characters, but it‚Äôs also next to impossible to reach the daily goals to earn XP if you just work on the characters. The free version makes it even harder to complete multiple lessons in a day to earn XP, as they changed from their ‚Äúonly lose a heart if you make a mistake‚Äù system to a ‚Äúspend energy for every single question‚Äù system. You have to either watch several ads or spend 500 gems to replenish your energy enough to move on to new lessons. There are also weird issues with grammar and how some questions/prompts are worded that feels like AI was involved in making the lessons. I have no interest in learning a language from AI. 

I also had an issue with their end of trial reminder and them charging me for the Super subscription. I had to go through Apple for a refund, which thankfully I was granted, but their customer service was handled by AI which left a bad taste in my mouth. I don‚Äôt appreciate that my ‚Äúreminder‚Äù was a push notification apparently sent in the early morning (when it would be easily missed), less than 2 days before the end of my trial. When I pointed out that the reminder came in later than it should have, Duolingo support didn‚Äôt acknowledge the error and just gave me repeat instructions on how to contact Apple for a refund (which it had already been acknowledged I‚Äôd received). It‚Äôs a small thing, but it‚Äôs frustrating. When I asked how people who don‚Äôt have push notifications enabled are meant to receive their reminder and if they could send reminders via email, I was told they didn‚Äôt ‚Äúhave specific information about‚Äù if that was possible or what happens if someone has notifications disabled. That seems like a glaring oversight. It just seems a bit scammy, like they are intentionally doing as little to remind users as possible so their trial will lapse, Duolingo will get their sub fee, and users will just roll with it because it‚Äôs more hassle to request a refund. I had previously had a Super subscription last year and liked the convenience of ad-free (I didn‚Äôt renew because my financial situation changed), but this recent issue just makes the company seem shady, and it made me rethink paying for Duolingo again in the future.

title: From good to not so good
content:
A few months ago I began using Duolingo on a daily basis. I enjoyed the quick lessons and the ability to gain hearts (only when you made a mistake a heart would be taken) through ads or gems. This made it easy to do multiple lessons and spend lots of time on the app. 
The newest update has sadly made learning incredibly difficult. Instead of hearts there is now energy. The twist is that you lose energy every question you answer. No matter if you get it wrong or right. This means you can get through MAYBE one lesson, spending on how much energy you have. There is a huge push from the company to buy the plan. Understandable until you realize the original goal of the app (and motto that they use frequently) is to provide ‚Äúfree‚Äù language learning. Making an app in which it is too difficult to learn languages using the free version does not make the app ‚Äúfree.‚Äù 
I learned quite a lot with the hearts. I could get through numerous lessons and actually spend 30+ minutes on the app. Now if I spend 5 minutes on the app that is too much. 
Due to it taking so long to get through the different sections, the content does not change. I have not learned anything in at least a week. I feel stagnant in learning and am considering ending my lessons on Duolingo. I urge the company to take a look at how unhappy its users are and make a change.

The amount of ads is also insanely annoying. Also, you always run out of energy before you can complete as much lessons as you want. I can only do 2 to 3 lessons a day when I would like to be progressing much faster. I cannot afford to pay for super Duolingo and very annoyed at the benefits that people who can‚Äôt afford to pay for are getting while I am stuck with the version that gave me adds every five minutes and I can‚Äôt even complete a significant amount of lessons to easily progress. The first lessons were fun, but now that it has gotten much harder without any warning I am very lost. The first lesson for sure help me learn the language languages and Duolingo also provides other things you can learn chess math and music. The chess one is very useful and I‚Äôve been learning a lot in it and I definitely recommend trying it out. All in all, if you are looking to learn a language, Duolingo is definitely the best language learning app I have tried, but you will definitely be annoyed with some of the things that you will experience while using the app as listed above. Thank you for reading my review and I hope you found it helpful.
